data.text: Stylish, Comfortable, and Quality Helmets with Sun Visor
ok so i haven‚Äôt worn a helmet in years. what‚Äôs a quality and comfortable and stylish helmet. preferably with a sun visor
Modern helmets come in all kinds of fits- I really suggest going to a shop and trying a few on. Forget the 'stylish' part unless it's a bonus on top of 'comfortable', 'light', 'well ventilated' etc.
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: I wear a Lumos Ultra which fits me well, great safety features and relatively stylish I guess but I‚Äôm 57 years old so my definition of stylish may not match others. Thankfully I haven‚Äôt had to verify the safety features yet.

data.text: Giro.
data.author: Johnny Johnson

data.text: I wear a Bell Citi. It might be what you are looking for.
data.author: Toby Betsen

data.text: If I may make a suggestion: look for a helmet with the MIPS system, it's proven to work, and due to the MIPS system itself, there is more space between your head and the styrofoam in the helmet, which helps air flow. My MET roam mips helmet saved my skull during a mountainbike accident in 2020 that was hard enough to break my face in 6 different places and knock most of my front teeth out. üëå
data.author: Christophe Van Steenbergen

data.text: ouch lucky to survive

data.text: Giro Fixture. Good value, good fitting system and has MIPS.

data.text: Do not buy the cheap foam ones. A girlfriend and I survived this. Blue helmet is driver side impact red is passenger

data.author: John Findlay

data.text:
I'm not sure there is such a thing as a truly stylish helmet, unless it's those dinosaur ones for small children that I would honestly buy and wear in a second. I have a Thousand helmet, which I got for two reasons: 1) It doesn't have a ton of vents in it, I've gotten patch scalp sunburns using helmets with a lot of vents, while this one has them, they're narrower and 2) It has a smallish visor that helps keep sun and rain out of my eyes but is built into the helmet, so it seems a little safer to me than the ones that click onto the front. https://www.explorethousand.com/products/mips-helmet
Chapter MIPS Helmet
explorethousand.com

data.text:
This is a good helmet, I just got one. Big discounts on at least in the UK as discontinued. Does not have MIPs but had POCs own version which they have now dropped in favour of MIPs. Huge step up in comfort and quality from my previous Giro Foray. One thing to be mindful of is the lack of adjustment on the ear straps which may make the helmet a poor fit for people with large or low ears. Mine just fits. Within 3 days of buying I slammed the car boot lid shut on my head, the helmet did an excellent job of protecting the space in my head which is obviously void of brains. So annoyed with myself. https://www.wiggle.co.uk/poc-omne-air-resistance-spin-helmet?lang=en&curr=GBP&dest=1&sku=101851078&utm_source=google&utm_term=&utm_campaign=&utm_medium=base&gclid=Cj0KCQjwlemWBhDUARIsAFp1rLUlKvAqZOBVkP9DKkDMYfkM2Ur8YhLikJMqvVEhkOxN2kVrydN1vVYaAtfxEALw_wcB&gclsrc=aw.ds

data.author: Kurt Franke

data.text: I wear a pro tec Bucky lassek, it's a lot lighter than others and has very little air flow and is not of Australia law standards and doesn't meet would safety guidelines.... I still use it dispute all the negatives because I feel it protects my Mellon alot better than regular helmets.. It covers alot more thoroughly and keeps me warm in colder weather. I have had many others that felt like over design foam with very little actual protection. Normal helmets sit on top of your head, a skate helmet covers overall head and offers little skin to actually be hurt. My helmet weighs about half of a normal one too.

data.text: In Australia it‚Äôs law to wear a helmet so it‚Äôs something I can‚Äôt avoid. The two best helmets I‚Äôve worn are the Bell Super8 and my current one is the LIVALL BH51 Helmet complete with lights and indicators (I work in Sydney). Both are comfortable, Stylish and have a visor. I hope this helps
data.author: Lachlan Johnson

data.text: Big money. A bike shop owner recently admitted to me that they make more money on accessories than from bike sales. I've never owned a helmet and I'm 63. Have always biked reasonably and the last 11 years through 40 countries, some 50.000 km. No issues so far. Of course, I don't do racing or mountain biking, in which case I would want a helmet. I'll wait until they equip cars with AI powered systems that will launch an airbag-like contraption at the cyclist just before collision. Spiderman could probably be valuable on that product development team.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: the entire business model of bike shops depend on the sale of accessories, and repairs. Markup on bikes is low, if they are properly prepped. Is a shop earning a livelihood a problem for you? And customers with hematomas, even just the mild ones, stop buying bikes and accessories, especially the dead ones. Not. A. Conspiracy. Your statement has a real "I drive without a seatbelt and I am proud of it, and anyone who wears a seatbelt must be a terrible driver" vibe to it. And it fails to take into account that you have to share the road with millions of other idiots. Please make sure your organ donor status is updated.
data.author: Ken Hill

data.text: hahahahahahhaha!!!!! Ahhh, the caucasity of confusing minor inconvenience, with persecution. Soooo, you are sooooo well versed in preventable head injuries, then, that you are now going to enlighten us all, that you know best, and that helmets don't work, and your cousin's bartender's dogwalker would have DIED if they had been wearing a helmet, or are we going to hear about all the unreported helmet poisoning that Big Helmets won't tell us about? Please proceed, guv'nor.
data.author: Ken Hill

data.text: Nothing of the sort. If some one wants to wear a helmet (or chooses not to wear a helmet) that is their choice and is neither any of my business and certainly none of yours!!! Your unqualified rant indicates, without a shadow of doubt that you are quite insane.
data.author: Tony Mitchelhill

data.text: Always the same arguments. Organs, seatbelts, blah, blah. The day the countries with helmet laws outnumber the ones without them, I will consider restricting my travel and living arrangements, lol, or maybe simply retiring from the human race. I'll probably be dead by then anyway! For the time being the world is fortunately still open, except Spain (one of my home countries, unfortunately), and Australia and NZ, which I wouldn't consider anyway.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: too many headshots, bud? Leaving it for others to clean up the mess, because you are too cool for laughably basic safety measures, is very on brand, though. Makes sense that you equate it with enduring the "persecution" of the laughably minor inconvenience of trying not to spread a highly contagious and deadly virus. How did Grampa get along without it? Grampa died, 30 years before his time, that's how.
data.author: Ken Hill

data.text: Well sorry for your loss, but your (or other people's) anecdotal experience does not justify making it an unnecessary obligation for everyone. And it is NOT a minor inconvenience. 200 EUR (fine imposed on me in Spain) is pretty much half my monthly salary/living expenses. Again, I'm not against helmets or their use by those who deem them necessary for themselves or children, but not for normal everyday NON-DANGEROUS cycling. And don't try to pathetically bring this in connection with viruses. Jesus. STDs also causes lots of harm and expenses to society as a whole. Where's the compulsory law for wearing condoms? Give me a break!
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: Well said. People like Ken Hill are truly the death star for any hope of increasing cycling rates or encouraging more people to ride bikes. Helmet laws in the countries to which you refer have resulted in massive decreases in the number of people cycling overall in those countries to the detriment of the overall physical health ( and mental health) of the general population.

data.text: it is well proven the compulsory helmet laws decrease cycling which in turn makes cycling more dangerous for those that do.

data.text: Thanks for asking. Even the cheap and cheerful helmets do an excellent job. All of them are at least decently effective, and the comfort and fit have taken a big step forward. As noted in the thread, the MIPS system equipped ones are even better at that crucial moment, and the cost is not that much extra.
data.author: Ken Hill

data.text: Pointless asking on social media. People will just recommend their personal choices. They're all much of a muchness, despite the marketing hype (all manufactured to EN1078). Try a few on as they do fit differently.

data.author: Donald Canard

data.text: Helmet fit varies substantially between brands and sometimes even between models. There is no substitute for going to shops and trying them on and see which one is the most comfortable. A lot of it will depend on the size and shape of your head. For me, Giro fits very well, and Bell and Smith are also quite comfortable. On the other hand, I was leaning towards getting one of those Bontrager wavecel helmets and then tried one on. Nope, not made for my head. I bought a Giro and it fits like a glove. But, for you, it might be the exact opposite. I also second (third) the recommendation to pay a little extra for one with MIPS.
data.author: Justin Stephen
